text: DON LEMON: I want to play

Secretary, Ben
Carson, addressing

his department employees
where he appears to compare
slaves to immigrants.

He begins talking about
the photos of people
who came here to Ellis Island.

BEN CARSON: Not eight hours a
day but 10, 12, 16 hours a day.
No such thing as a minimum wage.

They worked not for
themselves but for their sons

and their daughters
and their grandsons

and their granddaughters
that they might have
an opportunity in this land.
That's what America is about.

A land of dreams
and opportunities.

There were other
immigrants who came here
in the bottom of slave ships.

Worked even longer,
even harder for less.

But they too had a dream that
one day their sons, daughters,

grandsons, granddaughters, great
grandsons, great granddaughters

might pursue prosperity
and happiness in this land.

DON LEMON: So
Shermichael I have to go

to you first because you used
to work for Ben Carson at HUD.

Can you give us some insight
as to what he meant here
and why he would say that?

SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON:
Look Don, Dr. Carson

has released a statement that
was posted to his Facebook page

about an hour ago where he did
clarify the remarks that he

made earlier today
when he was addressing
the career staff at the agency.
And in those remarks--

in that clarification-- he made
it very clear that in no way

was he attempting to
compare the slave narrative
to the immigrant narrative.

The two are extremely
disparate and afforded

to that our ancestors
displayed when

being forced into
this country is

something that I
don't think anyone
would attempt to challenge.
DON LEMON: But Shermichael--

I understand what you're saying.
Hold on.
SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON: Don--

DON LEMON: No, no, no, no,
no-- it doesn't work that way.
SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON: Go ahead.

DON LEMON: Because you said
that he wasn't attempting

to but that's exactly
what he did by comparing
people from Ellis Island.

By the way, slaves couldn't
even come through Ellis Island

or see the Statue of
Liberty because it
wasn't during that time.
That's the whole point.

Those are two
different experiences.
But he himself was comparing it.

Maybe in his explanation he said
that, but if you listen to it,
that's what he said.

SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON: Don, I'm
not disagreeing with the facts

as it pertains to
slavery and immigrants

coming from European
countries into America.

That's not what I
am attempting to do.

What I'm saying is that Dr.
Carson made a statement.

Clearly, Dr. Carson has
recognized that his statements

were not the best
ones at that time
and clarified those statements.

He went to Armstrong's
Williams show, he provided--

DON LEMON: I get
what you're saying.
I get what you're saying.
You're saying he clarified it.

SHERMICHAEL
SINGLETON: He provided

even further
clarification on Facebook.

DON LEMON: I played the sound
bite from the Armstrong--
I get what you're saying.

You're saying that
you think he misspoke.
He didn't say it properly.
And he went back to clarify.

No, because we talk about
these subjects all the time.

And I want to play what Dr.
Carson said on Armstrong
Williams's radio show.
Listen.

BEN CARSON: I think
people need to actually
look up the word immigrant.

Whether you're voluntary
or involuntary,

if you come from outside to the
inside, you're an immigrant.

Whether you're legal
or you're illegal,

you come from the
outside to inside--
you're an immigrant.

Slaves came here as
involuntary immigrants.

But they still had the
strength to hold on.
DON LEMON: OK.

So an immigrant is
a person who comes

to another country
to live voluntarily
for a long time-- who comes.

And then he, as
Shermichael said,
he wrote about it on Facebook.

But he never said, I messed
up, or, what I intended to say
was--

he just said that
immigrants and slaves--

whether the narrative the two
share are entirely different
experiences--

and they shouldn't
be conflated--

I'm paraphrasing here-- but
that's kind of what he did.
